title: Indefinite orthogonal group
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, the indefinite orthogonal group, is the <a href="Lie%20group">Lie group</a> of all <a href="linear%20transformation">linear transformation</a>s of an "n"-<a href="dimension%20of%20a%20vector%20space">dimensional</a> real <a href="vector%20space">vector space</a> that leave invariant a <a href="nondegenerate%20form">nondegenerate</a>, <a href="symmetric%20bilinear%20form">symmetric bilinear form</a> of <a href="signature%20of%20a%20quadratic%20form">signature</a> , where . It is also called the pseudo-orthogonal group or generalized orthogonal group. The dimension of the group is .
The indefinite special orthogonal group, is the <a href="subgroup">subgroup</a> of consisting of all elements with <a href="determinant">determinant</a> 1. Unlike in the definite case, is not connected – it has 2 components – and there are two additional finite index subgroups, namely the connected and , which has 2 components – see "" for definition and discussion.
The signature of the form determines the group up to <a href="isomorphism">isomorphism</a>; interchanging "p" with "q" amounts to replacing the metric by its negative, and so gives the same group. If either "p" or "q" equals zero, then the group is isomorphic to the ordinary <a href="orthogonal%20group">orthogonal group</a> O("n"). We assume in what follows that both "p" and "q" are positive.
The group is defined for vector spaces over the <a href="real%20number">real</a>s. For <a href="Complex%20number">complex</a> spaces, all groups are isomorphic to the usual <a href="orthogonal%20group">orthogonal group</a> , since the transform formula_1 changes the signature of a form. This should not be confused with the <a href="indefinite%20unitary%20group">indefinite unitary group</a> which preserves a <a href="sesquilinear%20form">sesquilinear form</a> of signature .
In even dimension , is known as the <a href="%23Split%20orthogonal%20group">split orthogonal group</a>.
Examples.
The basic example is the <a href="squeeze%20mapping">squeeze mapping</a>s, which is the group of (the identity component of) linear transforms preserving the <a href="unit%20hyperbola">unit hyperbola</a>. Concretely, these are the matrices formula_2 and can be interpreted as "hyperbolic rotations," just as the group SO(2) can be interpreted as "circular rotations."
In physics, the <a href="Lorentz%20group">Lorentz group</a> is of central importance, being the setting for <a href="electromagnetism">electromagnetism</a> and <a href="special%20relativity">special relativity</a>. (Some texts use for the Lorentz group; however, is prevalent in <a href="quantum%20field%20theory">quantum field theory</a> because the geometric properties of the <a href="Dirac%20equation">Dirac equation</a> are more natural in .)

Topology.
Assuming both "p" and "q" are positive, neither of the groups nor are <a href="connected%20space">connected</a>, having four and two components respectively.
 is the <a href="Klein%20four-group">Klein four-group</a>, with each factor being whether an element preserves or reverses the respective orientations on the "p" and "q" dimensional subspaces on which the form is definite; note that reversing orientation on only one of these subspaces reverses orientation on the whole space. The special orthogonal group has components }, each of which either preserves both orientations or reverses both orientations, in either case preserving the overall orientation.
The <a href="identity%20component">identity component</a> of is often denoted and can be identified with the set of elements in that preserve both orientations. This notation is related to the notation for the <a href="orthochronous%20Lorentz%20group">orthochronous Lorentz group</a>, where the + refers to preserving the orientation on the first (temporal) dimension.
The group is also not <a href="compact%20space">compact</a>, but contains the compact subgroups O("p") and O("q") acting on the subspaces on which the form is definite. In fact, is a <a href="maximal%20compact%20subgroup">maximal compact subgroup</a> of , while is a maximal compact subgroup of .
Likewise, is a maximal compact subgroup of .
Thus, the spaces are homotopy equivalent to products of (special) orthogonal groups, from which algebro-topological invariants can be computed. (See <a href="Maximal%20compact%20subgroup%23Topology">Maximal compact subgroup</a>.)

Split orthogonal group.
In even dimensions, the middle group is known as the split orthogonal group, and is of particular interest, as it occurs as the group of <a href="T-duality">T-duality</a> transformations in string theory, for example. It is the <a href="split%20Lie%20group">split Lie group</a> corresponding to the complex <a href="Lie%20algebra">Lie algebra</a> so2"n" (the Lie group of the <a href="split%20real%20form">split real form</a> of the Lie algebra); more precisely, the identity component is the split Lie group, as non-identity components cannot be reconstructed from the Lie algebra. In this sense it is opposite to the definite orthogonal group , which is the <a href="compact%20real%20form">"compact" real form</a> of the complex Lie algebra.
The case corresponds to the <a href="multiplicative%20group">multiplicative group</a> of the <a href="split-complex%20number">split-complex number</a>s.
In terms of being a <a href="group%20of%20Lie%20type">group of Lie type</a> – i.e., construction of an algebraic group from a Lie algebra – split orthogonal groups are <a href="Chevalley%20group">Chevalley group</a>s, while the non-split orthogonal groups require a slightly more complicated construction, and are <a href="Steinberg%20group%20%28Lie%20theory%29">Steinberg groups</a>.
Split orthogonal groups are used to construct the <a href="generalized%20flag%20variety">generalized flag variety</a> over non-algebraically closed fields.
